inset, the denser phase becomes more stable at
8 GPa, in excellent agreement with the experimental data. Structural data from DFT calculations are also col-
lected in Supplementary Information. Our simulations also provide frequencies and pressure coefficients of the
IR- and Raman-active optical vibrations and, interestingly, show that some low-frequency modes corresponding
to the tilleyite phase become softer with increasing pressure and eventually vanish at the phase transition pressure
(Fig. 3 of SI). Furthermore, our theoretical data predict that post-tilleyite will be dynamically unstable above
illustrate the compression dependence of the lattice parameters and unit-cell volumes of both,
tilleyite and post-tilleyite phases. The experimental and theoretical values are in good agreement and show a
smooth and monotonous decrease under pressure. The strong anisotropy of tilleyite is described by the approx-
axes, respectively. These experimental axial compressibilities agree well with theoretical results:
axis is prominently harder (large incompressibility and rigidity of the
] disilicate units), which means that the bulk compressibility will be dominated by that of the
axes. The least-squares fit of a second-order Birch

80(2) GPa (75.3(4) GPa). These values reflect a slightly lower com-

ing to experimental (theoretical) results. Linear axial compressibilities indicate that the high-pressure phase is
The evolution of the DFT-calculated polyhedral unit volumes with compression is shown in Fig.
pression of the unit cell is dominated by the compression of the softer calcium-centered polyhedral units. In the
case of the low-pressure tilleyite phase, two types of polyhedra have a lower bulk modulus than the unit cell,
GPa, respectively (Table 6 of SI). After the transition, the remaining [CaO
89.0(9) GPa to that of the unit cell, but two other polyhedral units are more compressible under
compression: an 8-fold and the 9-fold coordinated Ca units with 62.7(3) and 83(1) GPa, respectively. Note that the
diversity of environments of the Ca atoms is not only defined by the number of oxygen neighbours but also by the
range of compressibilities of the different [CaO
] polyhedra, with bulk moduli as high as 139 (3) GPa.
Tilleyite was also studied at high-pressure high-temperature. The sample was progressively compressed and
heated up to 7.2 GPa and 402 °C while characterized collecting
powder XRD data. The HP-HT patterns
were indexed using the isolated single reflections and confirmed that the tilleyite structure remained stable in
that P-T range (Table 7 of SI). Due to the fact that the pressure is not constant during heating, we used a pertur-
bational method to estimate the thermal expansivity at low pressures, as described in ref.
has been successfully used to calculate the thermal expansivity under compression in other compounds
linear fit to our data yields a volumetric thermal expansion value of 3.5(4)·10
expansivity of tilleyite lies between those of CaCO
and it is only slightly smaller than those of calcium silicate

. This fact suggests therefore that the thermal
